job_title: Clinical Telehealth Therapist II in Toledo, OH
pros: Every social services job has pros and cons. At Harbor I was paid decently and had amazing insurance. I had enough PTO and was able to make my own hours, changing them with appropriate notice as I wished. As with any large organization serving the community it can be hectic at times. Clients no show sometimes making it stressful to get your minimum billing hours in. Overall would work here again.
cons: Client no shows. I never didn't meet minimum billing hours but golly gee, sometimes it was tighter than felt stress-free.

pros: Large client caseload, full-time position

job_title: Clinical Therapist II in Toledo, OH

cons: Short staff increases the workload

job_title: Clinical Telehealth Therapist II in Toledo, OH
pros: They offered telehealth jobs at the beginning of the pandemic.
cons: A case load of close to 100, inability to get ahold of supervisors, no ability to turn off new client availability, clients put in my schedule on days I didn't even work... The list goes on and on. When I left this job I followed every piece of protocol in their handbook as well as all of my ethical standards. Their handbook says you are insured until the last day of the month you terminate employment. They terminated my insurance on the first of the month I quit, which was a week before my last day. I didn't get my full final paycheck. I sent an official letter and was paid about 1/5 of what they owed me. I continue to pursue this. They refuse to provide documentation as to why my pay was docked and have locked me out of the system used to see paystubs, despite the handbook saying you have access to that system indefinitely. I am beyond disappointed in Harbor. I offered quality service, meeting all terms of my employment, and not only were working conditions rough while employed, but it's been a nightmare since leaving Harbor. Between not having insurance for an entire month I have documentation I should have it, missing pay for almost two whole weeks work, and not getting any response when I reach out to them to amicably remedy this, I cannot say enough how much I do not reccomend working here. Work anywhere else.

pros: Many of the employees there are great people. I learned a lot in my time there. In general it was a good place to work. With the exception of the upper management, it was a very positive experience.
cons: On several occasions upper management gave contradictory instructions on how to do something. Management also seemed to make decisions without understanding the full effects.

review_title: It's no longer a good place to work.
pros: Lots of great direct care staff.
cons: New senior management only cares about money.  They claim to care about the clients, but their decisions shows the opposite.  They do not care about, nor appreciate their employees.  Senior management has greatly reduced middle management, so the managers that are left have an increased workload to an already very stressful workload.

pros:
I've found that at Harbor, I can grow.  There is an excellent pathway for advancing my personal education with their reimbursement programs and a pretty generous referral bonus, especially for clinical staff.  There is room to grow with just a BA, to Masters, and onto independent licence. Harbor brings in speakers for CEU credits and the majority of them can be covered by internal conferences and training. It's nice to be celebrated and every so often they have a "Harbor-ized" giveaway's for us to use.  Typically very practical for office use. 

Bonus of the benefits, because I only have myself on my insurance and not my family, Harbor pays for my insurance and I get a cash pay out every month in my check for only having myself on the plan.  They pay us for not having to cover additional family members.

The flexible scheduling is really helpful for home life.  I like living in Northwest Ohio. The cost of living is crazy cheap compared to Los Angeles where I previously lived.  My team that I work with, we work very well together and I feel that I could easily talk to my supervisor if a problem arose.
cons:
Communication from top leadership could be better, they are trying.  They acknowledge it could be better.    

We are VERY busy.  There is no down time.  Not that you need downtime but Harbor is busy.  If you like twiddling your thumbs, Harbor isn't for you.

Our offices are spread out throughout the NW Ohio area so it could be a drive depending on your position.  Also, because we are so spread out, sometimes it's hard to know what is going on at other locations.

pros:
Pay
Benefits
Co-workers
Helping people gain their independence
cons:
Lack of acknowledgement from management. 
Their focus is supposed to be people centered services but behind the scenes it is all about money. 
Micromanaging. 
Unorganized. 
Work overload.

pros: There are many caring, dedicated clinical and line staff throughout the Harbor organization.   The greatest asset of this organization are these staff members!
cons: Terrible senior management!  Cut throat people in senior level positions that care nothing about anything but their own positions and advancement, or next step!

review_title: Avoid this dumpster fire of an organization at all costs!
pros: The team I worked with was supportive and open.  There was initially a lot of flexibility with my schedule which worked great for having young children, but that changed as the micromanaging and the senior management added more responsibilities.
cons: Senior management absolutely does not care about the clients needs, their staff, or anything else except for money.  They are a non-profit but operate as a for profit.  The senior management likes to come up with programming for locations without asking for input from the populations that location serves and then places the responsibility for success on that locations clinical manager.  Meanwhile they will balk at implementing programming to facilitate treatment fidelity for existing clients.  This organization exists only to make long term patients, not to provide true therapy and healing.  Previous reviews stating that senior management is open and approachable is a lie and anyone who works there will say the same if given the opportunity to speak privately.  The CEO has a very fragile ego and will verbally berate anyone who “questions” him.  The unit expectations for clinical therapists are currently at 30 per week, and you can definitely anticipate that increasing.  The Union is an absolute joke that does not represent the interest of the union members, rather they negotiate in favor of the company.  When the government was offering business loans and grants to assist businesses due to the coronavirus lockdown, Harbor fired a bunch of staff so they could qualify for the grant instead of the loan, further showing that the company cares more about money than the people that work for them and the clients they serve.  And last, the CEO made $430K in the last reported financials, and all this while he has been at the helm of running up budget deficits due to poor leadership choices, such as trying to expand services to Cincinnati and Florida.  Meanwhile, an LSW could count themselves lucky to be offered $41K and an LISW $55K.

pros: Good benefits package. Opportunity for career growth.
